column1: Authors
column2: Title & Publication
column4: Summary
column5: Summary

column1: Erik Brynjolfsson, Danielle Li, & Lindsey R. Raymond
column2: Generative AI at Work – Quarterly Journal of Economics
column4: Studied a staggered rollout of an AI assistant for 5,000+ customer support agents. Access to the tool increased issues resolved per hour by ~14% on average (and +34% for novice workers, with minimal gains for experienced workers)[1]. The AI helpdesk disseminated best practices, boosted productivity especially for junior staff, improved customer sentiment, and reduced employee turnover[2].
column5:
• Studies staggered deployment of AI chat assistant for ~5,000 customer support agents. Tool built on (pre-ChatGPT) GPT-3; rollout Oct 2020 - May 2021.
• Tool increased successfully resolved user chats by 15% per agent per hour. Time per chat declined, number of simultaneous chats per agent increased, and slightly higher % of chats are resolved successfully.
• Most of the effect comes from newer & less skilled workers, who see 30% increase in chats resolved/hour. Tools makes workers w/ 2 months experience perform like those w/ 6 months exp. Experienced & higher skilled workers see small speed gains; best workers see small quality declines.
• Agents who follow AI recommendations more closely have bigger productivity gains, which last even during AI API outages.
• Biggest improvements come on "relatively rare" problems, where agents have less experience but AI training data exists. AI is little help on very rare problems.
• AI improves customer satisfaction and drives reduces attrition of newer agents.

column1: Shakked Noy & Whitney Zhang
column2: Experimental evidence on the productivity effects of generative AI – Science
column4: Ran a randomized experiment with 453 professionals doing writing tasks, with half given access to ChatGPT. ChatGPT raised productivity substantially: average task completion time fell ~40% and output quality improved ~18%[3]. The productivity boost was larger for weaker writers, narrowing skill disparities[4]. Many treated workers adopted ChatGPT in their real jobs afterward.
column5:
• Gave 400+ college educated professionals writing tasks, half of them prompted to use ChatGPT (2023).
• ChatGPT group took 37% less time on tasks (17 minutes vs 27 minutes), got 0.45 SD higher evaluations. In fixed-time task, ChatGPT group scored 0.39 SD better.
• Primarily substitution effect: 68% of treatment group submitted ChatGPT output without editing; spending longer on task after producing AI output didn't increase quality. Raw ChatGPT output scored similarly to human+AI output.
• AI halved time spent drafting the response and doubled time spent editing. Participants were willing to pay ~0.5% of their monthly salary for ChatGPT access.
• AI use increased job satisfaction by 0.4 SD, feelings of self-efficacy by 0.2 SD, fear of automation in subject's profession by 0.26 SD, belief that AI will boost productivity by .39 SD, and overall optimism about AI advances by 0.2 SD.
• In follow-up survey, treatment group were more likely (33% vs 18%) to be using ChatGPT in their jobs; those who weren't mostly said it was because AI didn't have relevant context specific knowledge for their field or company.

column1: Leonardo Gambacorta, Han Qiu, Shuo Shan, Daniel Rees
column2: Generative AI and labour productivity: a field experiment on coding – BIS Working Paper No. 1208
column4: Conducted a field experiment at Ant Group where a team of programmers received an AI coding assistant (“CodeFuse”) while a control group did not. Programmers with the AI tool wrote ~55% more code (lines) than those without[5]. Productivity gains were statistically significant only for junior developers; senior programmers saw little change, apparently using the tool less often[6]. This suggests AI coding assistance can dramatically boost output for less-experienced coders.
column5:
• Experiment from Sept - Nov 2023 at Ant Group involving ~1,200 coders, split between those with and without access to CodeFuse, a new coding assistance LLM. Primary measure = lines of code produced/week
• Group with access to LLM saw a 53% increase in code production relative to control group. Of this, 11-18pp was due to coders using direct LLM outputs, and 36-43pp due to time saving, likely from the LLM helping coders overcome obstacles in coding.
• Entry level and junior coders had 67% increase in code produced; senior coders no significant change.
• Senior coders used AI 70% less than juniors, but acceptance rate for AI suggestions (15-20%) was the same across groups.

column1: Kevin Z. Cui, Mert Demirer, Sonia Jaffe, Leon Musolff, Sida Peng, Tobias Salz
column2: The Effects of Generative AI on High-Skilled Work: Evidence from Three Field Experiments with Software Developers(working paper)
column4: Analyzed three large RCTs at Microsoft, Accenture, and another firm (~4,867 software developers in total) where some were given GitHub Copilot (an AI code autocompletion tool). Pooled results show developers with AI completed 26% more tasks per week than the control group[7][8]. Adoption and gains were higher for less-experienced developers. In other words, AI coding tools significantly improved productivity, especially for junior programmers.
column5:
• Pools three experiments randomizing access to Copilot among SWE at Microsoft (Sept 2022), Accenture (July 2023), and another Fortune 100 company (Oct 2023).
• Use of Copilot increased weekly completed tasks (pull requests) by 26%, commits by 13.5%, and number of code compiles by 38%.
• MSFT only: Approval rate for PRs rose 10% after Copilot adoption; other measures of quality (number of comments, number of merge conflicts, odds of approval by any reviewer) saw no significant change.
• MSFT only: newer employees 9% more likely to adopt Copilot and more likely to continue using, juniors 5% more likely to adopt; newer employees increase output by 27-39% with Copilot, long-tenured by 8-13%; juniors increase by 21-40%, seniors by 7-16%.

column1: Menaka Hampole, Dimitris Papanikolaou, Lawrence D.W. Schmidt, Bryan Seegmiller
column2: Artificial Intelligence and the Labor Market – NBER Working Paper No. 33509
column4: Developed task-level AI exposure measures for U.S. occupations (2010–2023) and studied firm-level outcomes. They find tasks with higher AI exposure subsequently see lower labor demand[9]. Within firms, two factors matter: the average exposure of a job’s tasks (which depresses demand) and the concentration of that exposure in a few tasks (which offsets losses by allowing workers to shift to other tasks)[10]. Causal tests confirm these patterns[11][12]. Overall employment effects are modest – reduced demand in AI-exposed roles is largely offset by productivity-driven job growth at firms adopting AI[13].
column5:
• Develops new measure of task-level exposure to AI from 2010 to 2023 (largely before generative AI). 
• They identify two dimensions of exposure: the average replaceability of a job's task (higher = reduced demand) and the proportion of a job's tasks that are highly exposed (lower = offset lossess, as newly productive workers shift to other tasks).
• Within-firm employment in most exposed occupations fell by ~3% relative to least exposed occupations over the studied time period. But at the economy-wide level, employment in those occupations actually rose slightly, because the firms with more of those workers expanded due to greater productivity gains from AI.
• Some less-exposed occupations, like food preparation and serving, experienced declines that may be due to slower productivity gains from their employers as a result of lower AI adoption.

column1: Anders Humlum, Emilie Vestergaard
column2: Large Language Models, Small Labor Market Effects – NBER Working Paper No. 33777
column4: Examined early labor-market impacts of AI chatbot adoption in Denmark by linking firm AI adoption surveys to worker administrative records. Using diff-in-diff, they find essentially no short-run effect on earnings or hours worked – ruling out changes beyond about 2% even two years after adoption[14]. This “zero” result holds even for intensive AI users, early adopters, high-investment firms, young workers, etc. Adoption did prompt some occupational switching and task restructuring within firms, but no net change in total hours or pay[15]. The authors conclude that fears of imminent AI-driven disruption are not yet borne out in aggregate data[16].
column5:
• Examines labor impact of AI chatbots in Denmark by surveying 25,000 workers in 11 exposed occupations in late 2024 and linking individual survey responses to government labor market records of earnings, hours, and occupation.
• Even though AI adoption in Denmark is similar to the U.S., and the Danish labor market is highly flexible, they find zero effects of AI chatbot adoption on earnings or hours, even for workers who use AI tools daily or work in firms that encourage the use of AI.
• On the other hand, they find that AI users are slightly more likely to have switched to new jobs, although without net gains in hours or earnings.
• Firms that encourage and invest in AI use have seen no changes in employment levels, wage bills, job creation or destruction, or composition of hiring and firing decisions. This result holds even when isolating early career workers.

column1: Erik Brynjolfsson, Bharat Chandar, Ruyu Chen
column2: Canaries in the Coal Mine? Six Facts about the Recent Employment Effects of AI -- Stanford Digital Economy Lab WP
column4: Used high-frequency payroll data (ADP) to document how U.S. jobs in AI-exposed occupations have changed since generative AI’s widespread adoption. They report that entry-level workers (age 22–25) in the most AI-exposed occupations experienced a 13% decline in employment relative to less-exposed groups (after controlling for firm shocks)[17]. Meanwhile, employment for older workers in the same jobs or for less-exposed occupations continued to grow[18]. The adjustment came mostly via reduced hiring (employment) rather than wage cuts. Losses were concentrated in roles where AI is more likely to automate (vs. augment) tasks[19]. These patterns provide early evidence that the AI revolution is disproportionately impacting junior hires in certain white-collar fields.
column5:
• Use ADP payroll data to examine changes in the labor market since the release of generative AI tools.
• Since 2022, early career workers in the most exposed jobs have seen a 13% decline in employment relative to less exposed fields and more experienced workers. The AI effect for early career workers showed up primarily in employment level, not wages.
• Employment declines were concentrated in fields where AI is more likely to automate than augment human labor, which they measure by estimating whether Claude queries in an occupation substitute or complement for relevant tasks.

column1: Sarah E. Eckhardt, Nathan Goldschlag
column2: AI and Jobs: The Final Word (Until the Next One) – EIG Report
column4: Analyzed U.S. Current Population Survey data (2022–2025) using multiple occupation-level AI exposure indices. They find no evidence of AI-driven job losses so far. In fact, the unemployment rate rose less for the most AI-exposed quintile of workers (+0.3 percentage points) than for the least exposed quintile (+0.9 pp) since ChatGPT’s release[20]. Similarly, highly exposed workers did not exit the labor force at higher rates (if anything, they exit slightly less) and are not systematically shifting to less-exposed occupations. In sum, high-AI-exposure workers are, if anything, faring better in the current labor market than other workers, contradicting “job apocalypse” fears[21][20].
column5:
• Finds no aggregate effects of generative AI on the labor force in an analysis of Current Population Survey data from 2022 to 2025 using multiple job- and firm-level AI exposure measures.
• Since 2022, the unemployment rate has risen more for the least AI-exposed workers than for the most.
• The share of workers exiting the labor force is lowest (and stable) for the most exposed quintile of workers.
• The most AI-exposed quintile of workers switches occupations more often than less exposed workers, but the switching rate is lower than it was before the Covid pandemic and has not risen since 2022.
• Unemployment for young workers (22 - 27 year olds) in the most exposed quintile has risen, but less quickly and from lower levels than for young workers in other quintiles.
• Isolating to the information sector, where businesses are three times more likely than average to say they use AI, employment trends show no break with the introduction of generative AI.
• Publishing and data processing, the sectors most likely to use AI, have seen roughly flat employment since 2022 after Covid-era surges. [APR: not a very robust DiD measure, but non fancy stuff is maybe better]

column1: Jacob Dominski, Yong Suk Lee
column2: Advancing AI Capabilities and Evolving Labor Outcomes (arXiv preprint)
column4: Constructed a dynamic AI Exposure indexfor occupations (using GPT-4 and Claude to assess tasks) and compared CPS outcomes before vs. after the late-2022 AI breakthrough. They find occupations with higher AI exposure saw larger declines in employment and full-time work, and bigger rises in unemployment, from late 2022 to late 2024[22][23]. The negative effects concentrate among certain groups – notably older and younger workers, men, and college-educated workers in high-exposure jobs[24]. Occupations heavy in complex reasoning tasks had greater drops in employment and hours, whereas manual task-based jobs were less affected[23]. This suggests nascent AI-driven labor shifts along both the extensive (job loss) and intensive (hours) margins, with heterogeneous impacts by demographic and task type.
column5:
• Using a novel measure of AI exposure, they analyze CPS data to identify labor market shifts after the release of ChatGPT.
• Finds that from 2022 to 2025, a 10 point increase (on a 0 to 100 scale) in AI exposure is associated with a 5-8pp decline in total employment and a 0.64-0.68pp increase in unemployment. A 10 point increase is also associated with small hours reductions and ~1pp decline in the share of full time (relative to part time) workers. 
• Attempt to control for post-pandemic effects on remote work.

column1: Martha Gimbel, Molly Kinder, Joshua Kendall, Maddie Lee
column2: Evaluating the Impact of AI on the Labor Market: Current State of Affairs – Yale Budget Lab
column4: Took a broad, aggregate look at U.S. labor market data ~33 months after ChatGPT’s debut. They find no discernible economy-wide disruption attributable to AI (yet). The pace of occupational mix change since late 2022 is only slightly above historical norms and actually predates GenAI’s introduction[25][26]. Moreover, occupations deemed more “AI-exposed” have not seen greater employment declines or higher unemployment than other occupations so far[27]. In short, despite popular anxieties, the overall U.S. job market has not (to date) shown significant AI-related dislocation, though the authors caution that better data and longer horizons are needed for future monitoring.
column5:
* Broad look at the impact of AI on the US labor market from late 2022 to late 2025.
• No discernible disruption to the aggregate labor market, but they note that past technological disruptions have taken decades, not years, to play out.
• The overall mix of jobs has changed at about the same rate as in past technological eras, and any increase in disruption started in January 2021 or before. The industries that have shown the biggest shifts since 2022--information, finance, and professional services--have historically had higher than average rates of volatility, with no recent increase. Overall economic volatilty is lower than in the mid-twentieth century.
• The job market for recent grads (20-24) has been changing slightly faster than for older grads (25-34) since about 2023. This could be evidence of AI disruption to labor market entrants, but the different is small and consistent with a slowing overall labor market hitting younger workers harder.
• Using OpenAI AI exposure estimates, they find no trends in employment or unemployment associated with relative exposure level.
• Using Anthropic's current usage measure, they find no trend in employment or unemployment in occupations with high AI usage, whether coded as augmenting or automating usage.
• They note data limitations: OpenAI's exposure measure captures theoretical ability for automation, not actual workplace adoption and diffusion. Also note that OpenAI exposure measure is only weakly correlated with Anthropic's usage measure.

column1: Bouke Klein Teeselink
column2: Generative AI and Labor Market Outcomes: Evidence from the United Kingdom(working paper)
column4: Used U.K. firm and vacancy data (2021–2025) to study differential impacts in firms/jobs with varying exposure to LLM capabilities. Results show high-LLM-exposed firms cut total employment, especially entry-level hiring. These firms sharply pulled back on new hires in technical roles (e.g. software, data analysis)[28]. At the occupation level, highly exposed roles saw fewer job postings and lower advertised salaries relative to less-exposed roles[29]. Notably, the contraction is concentrated in the high-wage segment of the labor market – high-paying firms and occupations saw significant job and pay declines, whereas low-wage jobs were largely unaffected[30]. This implies generative AI may reduce demand for certain high-skilled jobs, potentially compressing wage inequality from the top down.
column5:
• Combines private UK labor market data with a standard measure of AI exposure (Eloundou et al) to estimate the impact of AI since 2022 on employment, wages, pay dispersion, job seniority, and hiring dynamics.
• Finds the most exposed firms experienced a 4.5% fall in total employment relative to firms without exposure, with the decline skewed toward junior positions.
• The most exposed firms posted 16pp fewer job ads, with the biggest declines in technical and creative roles and small increases in customer-facing roles.
• Highly exposed occupations saw a 23% decline in job postings, and became marginally less likely to allow remote work.
• These effects were concentrated in high-wage jobs and firms, suggesting that LLMs may, initially at least, compress wages rather than increase inequality.

column1: Danqing Chen, Carina Kane, Austin Kozlowski, Nadav Kunievsky, James A. Evans
column2: The (Short-Term) Effects of LLMs on Unemployment and Earnings (arXiv preprint)
column4: Analyzed U.S. occupational outcomes in the wake of ChatGPT’s release by comparing high vs. low AI-exposure occupations. They find no spike in unemployment for highly exposed jobs, but do detect a significant earnings increase for workers in high-exposure occupations after late 2022[31][32]. In other words, early adjustments to generative AI appear to be happening through wage growth (productivity gains) rather than job losses[31][32]. These results suggest that in the short run, generative AI’s main labor market effect has been to raise the earnings of workers in AI-intensive jobs, with little evidence of displacement so far.
column5:
• Using an AI exposure measure based on Claude prompts, analyzes US unemployment rates and wages before and after the release of ChatGPT.
• Find that the release of ChatGPT raised earnings for workers in highly exposed occupations by an average of $89 per week, with the effect concentrated in 2024 and 2025. They find no observable effect on unemployment rates. 
• Agree with the EIG finding that the most exposed occupations have consistently lower unemployment than less exposed occupations.

column1: Fabrizio Dell'Acqua, Edward McFowland III, Ethan R. Mollick, etc.
column2: Navigating the Jagged Technological Frontier: Field Experimental Evidence of the Effects of AI on Knowledge Worker Productivity and Quality
column4: Field RCT with 750+ consultants given access to GPT 4 vs control. More tasks completed, faster, higher quality, but varied by task and most pronounced for “AI amenable” tasks
column5:
• RCT in 2023 with ~750 BCG consultants given access to either no AI, GPT-4, or GPT-4 with a prompt engineering overview.
• For tasks within the distribution of 2023 AI capabilities, consultants with AI access completed 12% more tasks, finished each task 25% faster, and acored 40% better on a quality rubric. The effect was strongest among below average consultants, who improved quality by 43%, but still positive among above average consultants, whoc improved quality by 17%.
• For tasks outside the frontier of AI capabilities, consultants with AI access were 19pp less accurate than those without AI.
• How consultants used AI also varied: some (the paper calls them centaurs) delegated tasks to the AI while completing other tasks themselves, while others (cyborgs) integrating AI into their task flow and interacted with the chatbot more continuously.

column1: Xiang Hui, Oren Reshef, & Luofeng Zhou
column2: The Short-Term Effects of Generative Artificial Intelligence on Employment: Evidence from an Online Labor Market
column4: Upwork panel of freelancers before/after chatgpt, DallE2, midjourney releases. In affected categories, freelancers’ employment and earnings fell in the short run
column5:
• Uses data from Upwork to analyze the employment and earnings of freelancers before and after the release of ChatGPT, Dall-E 2, and Midjourney in 2022.
• Find that the release of ChatGPT reduced the number of monthly job offerings in writing-related occupations by 2% and reduced monthly earnings on Upwork by 5.2%.
• The release of Dall-E 2 and Midjourney similarly reduced monthly job postings in related fields by 3.7% and earnings by 9.4%.

column1: Antti Kauhanen & Petri Rouvinen
column2: Assessing early labor market effects of generative AI: Evidence from population data
column4: Synthetic DiD by occupation across full Finnish population. Post ChatGPT no negative short-run employment effects, wages rose relatively more in highly exposed occupations
column5:
• Used data on all wage earners in Finland to assess the impact of ChatGPT on the labor market from Nov 2022 - Nov 2024.
• Find no significant differences in changes in wage or employment levels between more and less exposed occupations.
• They suggest LLMs may be both complementing and substituting for human labor in the short term, raising productivity in some tasks and replacing humans in others, with close to zero net effect so far.

column1: Erik Engberg, Mark Hellsten, Farrukh Javed, Magnus Lodefalk, Radka Sabolová, & Sarah Schroeder
column2: Artificial intelligence, hiring and employment: job postings evidence from Sweden
column4: Covers 2014-2022 Swedish job postings Ai exposed firms hire more AI related workers Compositional changes but no large aggregate losses
column5:
• Combines universal Swedish employment data from 2014 - 2022 with a measure of occupational AI exposure.
• Finds that (pre widespread LLM use), firms more exposed to AI competition hire more AI workers and use more AI services.
• The net effect of pre-LLM AI was to increase hiring for both AI and non-AI related roles, but without substantial resulting productivity increases overall. They suggest that AI exposed firms may be using AI to augment existing roles and hrie more complementary workers, rather than using it to replace workers.

column1: Jonathan Hartley, Filip Jolevski, Vitor Melo, & Brendan Moore
column2: The Labor Market Effects of Generative Artificial Intelligence
column4: Surveys adoption finding rise from 30% LLM use in Dec. 2024 to 36.7% in Sept. 2025 Small effect on wages in more exposed occupations, no significant effect on job openings or total jobs
column5:
• Two elements: survey of AI use in the workplace and analysis of AI's effects on wages and employment since 2022 using private job posting data and BLS wage data.
• Previous surveys show varying AI adoption: a 2023 Pew survey found 20% teens used ChatGPT for schoolwork; a 2024 Pew survey similarly found 20% of American workers had used it at work at least once/year; and the biweekly US Census Business Trends and Outlook Survey found that 3.7% of firms used AI in Sept 2023 and 5.4% in Feb 2024.
• This paper surveyed a nationally representative sample of U.S. workers and found LLM use at work rose from 30% in Dec 2024, to 43% in March/April 2025, to 46% in June/July 2025. Among LLM users, 1/3 said they used it every work day.
• Their analysis of job postings and BLS data found that more AI-exposed occupations saw wage gains since late 2022, while employment levels and job postings did not change.

column1: Yueling Huang
column2: The Labor Market Impact of Artificial Intelligence: Evidence from US Regions
column4: Pre chatGPT: data from 2010-2021 Finds larger decline in epop ratio in commuting zones with higher AI adoption Effect mainly in manufacturing and low skilled serviced sectors and young+old employees. Worse for men than women
column5:
• Examines labor impact of AI in the U.S. from 2010 to 2021 by exploiting regional variation in AI adoption.
• Areas with higher AI adoption experienced larger declines in employment-to-population ratio, with the decline beying disproportionately borne by low-skill services and manufacturing sectors, non-STEM workers, men, young and old workers.

column1: Ole Teutloff, Johanna Einsiedler, Otto Kässi, Fabian Braesemann, Pamela Mishkin, & R. Maria del Rio-Chanona
column2: Winners and losers of generative AI: Early Evidence of Shifts in Freelancer Demand
column4: LLM-based clustering shows 10% of job postings are substitutable by GenAI. • GenAI cut demand for substitutable skill clusters by up to 50% in short-term roles. • Demand for some complementary AI clusters like machine learning increased. • Demand for novice workers in complementary roles declined. • Aggregate freelance demand did not decrease after the ChatGPT launch.
column5:
• Uses data from a leading freelancing platform to categorize skills as substitutable, complementary, or unaffected by LLMs. Concludes that about 10% of job postings on the platform are for substitutable skills.
• Finds that after the release of ChatGPT, labor demand rose for  complementary and unaffected skills, and declined by 20-50% relative to trend for substitutable skills, such as writing and translation.
• Although complementary skills saw overall increased demand, some elements declined. Demand for ML programming grew by 24% relative to trend, demand for chatbot development tripled, while demand for novice workers fell overall.

column1: R. Maria del Rio-Chanona, Ekkehard Ernst, Rossana Merola, Daniel Samaan, Ole Teutloff
column2: AI and Jobs: A review of theory, estimates, and evidence
column4: Meta analysis of RCTs, field experiments, and other data. New classification of task complexity. Bigger productivity gains in RCTs than field experiments. Mild evidence of declining demand for junior workers in writing/translation. Bigger declease in novice jobs in AI complementary work from surveys/admin data. Lit gaps include limited types of LLMs used, tech centric AI exposure measures and variance, use of simple tasks
column5:
• Surveys a wide range of studies of AI impact on productivity to find that productivity gains vary heavily based on context. Gains are 20-60% in RCTs, 15-30% in field experiments.
• In simple tasks, novice workers seem to benefit the most. In more complex tasks, evidence is mixed on whether novice or experienced workers benefit more.
• In writing and translation tasks, digital trace data show rising demand for AI and substitution of machines for humans, along with mild evidence of declining demand for novice workers.
• The most recent studies show more substantial declines in demand for novice workers in AI complementary jobs.

column1: Guy Lichtinger & Seyed Hosseini
column2: Generative AI as Seniority-Biased Technological Change: Evidence from U.S. Résumé and Job Posting Data
column4: Following GenAI adoption, junior employment declines sharply in adopting firms relative to non-adopters, while senior employment remains largely unchanged. The junior decline is concentrated in occupations most exposed to GenAI and is driven by slower hiring rather than increased separations or promotions.
column5:
• Using private data sets from Linkedin and Revelio Labs to track firm-level employment by seniority from 2015 to 2025, and cross-check with generative AI adoption, as measured by whether a firm hires for an "AI integrator" to implement or operate AI in its work.
• Find that in firms that hire AI integrators, employment for junior workers in AI exposed roles declines sharply relative to non adoptors. Senior employment doesn't change. The junior decline is driven by reduced hiring, not greater firing.

column1: Dirk Czarnitzki,  Gastón P. Fernández, & Christian Rammer
column2: Artificial intelligence and firm-level productivity
column4: German firms: positive and significant associations between the use of AI and firm productivity
column5: • Looks at the effect of AI adoption in German firms in 2022 (pre LLM era), finding significant positive impact on productivity.

column1: Samuel Muehlemann
column2: AI Adoption and Workplace Training (IZA working paper)
column4: 2019-2021 data, AI adoption reduces the provision of continuing training for incumbent workers while increasing the share of high-skilled new hires and decreasing medium-skilled hires, thereby contributing to skill polarization. However, AI adoption also increases the number of apprenticeship contracts, particularly in small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).
column5: • Looks at AI adoption in German firms from 2019 to 2021, finding that adoption reduced training for new workers, increased the share of high-skilled hires, reduced the share of medium-skilled hires, and increased the number of apprenticeship contracts.

column1: Mark A. Chen & Joanna Wang
column2: Displacement or Augmentation? The Effects of AI Innovation on Workforce Dynamics and Firm Value
column4: 2007-2023 US patent data: AI innovations related to high-level cognition (i.e., language, decision-making, engagement, learning, or creativity) augment human labor, while those related to low-level cognition (i.e., perception or motor control) displace it.
column5:
• Uses data on AI related patents in the US from 2007 to 2023.
• AI innovations related to high-level cognition (i.e., language, decision-making, engagement, learning, or creativity) augmented human labor, while those related to low-level cognition (i.e., perception or motor control) displace it.
